posts.name:
Shail Khiyara
Shail Khiyara
posts.content:
𝗔𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗰 𝗔𝗜 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗽𝗼𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗮𝗹 𝘁𝗼 𝗿𝗲𝗱𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗽𝗿𝗶𝘀𝗲 𝗮𝘂𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗶𝘁 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘀 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗯𝗶𝗴 𝗾𝘂𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀.

Like 𝗝𝗮𝗻𝘂𝘀, the Roman god with two faces, agentic AI presents a dual narrative: one of immense promise and one of significant caution. On one side, it offers a transformative leap in automating unstructured workflows, enabling enterprises to streamline operations in ways previously unimaginable. On the other, it demands we confront foundational challenges in integration, ethics, and ROI.

◆ 𝗖𝘆𝗰𝗹𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗼𝗳 𝗔𝘂𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: The idea that automation evolves in predictable cycles assumes every leap is just a continuation of the past. But agentic AI isn’t simply the next step—it introduces fundamentally new risks. For instance, in high-stakes workflows like compliance reporting, the unpredictability of probabilistic systems could lead to regulatory fines or reputational damage.

◆ 𝗦𝗲𝗮𝗺𝗹𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: The belief that AgenticAI will seamlessly replace backend business logic oversimplifies enterprise ecosystems (also an interesting Satya prediction). Consider ERP platforms like SAP or Oracle—systems deeply entrenched in operations. Moving to an AI-centric architecture would require an overhaul, fraught with risks and costs.

◆ 𝗚𝘂𝗮𝗿𝗮𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝗥𝗢𝗜: Enterprises are still unlocking value from past automation investments like RPA. Without clear, measurable outcomes, agentic AI risks following a similar path of unfulfilled ROI promises, with hidden costs in maintenance and scaling.

◆ 𝗘𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝗡𝗲𝘂𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆: Automating roles like data entry could displace workers and create regulatory risks from opaque AI decisions, especially in sensitive industries like finance.

Blending deterministic workflows with probabilistic agents sounds innovative, but in high-stakes environments, even minor errors can cascade into major consequences. The shift to an "AI-PI" interoperability paradigm may sound groundbreaking, but replacing decades of API standardization is no small feat. And safeguarding proprietary enterprise data in AI systems adds another layer of complexity.

undoubtedly holds incredible promise, particularly for unstructured workflows like document analysis. But the 𝐉𝐚𝐧𝐮𝐬-𝐟𝐚𝐜𝐞𝐝 nature of this technology reminds us to proceed with both optimism and caution. Transformative potential requires rigorous planning, measurable value delivery, and careful consideration of societal impact.

What’s your take? Are these challenges surmountable, or are we rushing to embrace agentic AI without addressing the big questions? Let’s discuss!

comments.commentText:
Well, we're back to the "How Do You Eat an Elephant Approach".

The largest successes have been seen with a phased, earned-value approach to Agentic AI. This can significantly de-risk adoption and accelerate time-to-value. Lessons learned so far -

- Start Small, Prove Value

- Hybrid Integration

- Iterative Expansion

- Use Appropriate Implementation and Evaluation Methodologies
Impact Engineering has proven significantly more effective than other methodologies so far.

- Continuous Monitoring & Adjustment

This approach allows organizations to:

- Mitigate Financial Risk: Avoid large upfront investments and ensure a positive return.

- Accelerate Adoption: Early successes build momentum and encourage wider acceptance of agentic AI across the organization.

- Reduce Integration Challenges: A phased approach allows for gradual integration with existing systems, minimizing disruption and risk.

- Offset systemic risk: by transferring the cost and effort to an exogenous unit with SLA and quality guidelines, companies can both validate new techs/processes and avoid functional or financial downside.
Treu, that's why APA may play better in enterprises in short term.

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! The dual nature of agentic AI is compelling. Balancing innovation with ethical considerations will be key. Looking forward to the discussion!

posts.name:
Ajay Prasad
Ajay Prasad
posts.content:
𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝗮𝗻 𝗢𝘄𝗻𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗠𝗶𝗻𝗱𝘀𝗲𝘁 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝘀 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝗽𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗼 𝗣𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿𝗳𝘂𝗹 𝗢𝘂𝘁𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘀 

In healthcare, every action directly impacts patient outcomes, making an ownership mindset essential. This approach to responsibility isn’t about simply completing tasks, it’s about fostering accountability and creating a culture where every team member actively contributes to success.

At RepuGen and GMR Web Team, we believe in empowering individuals and teams with the tools and mindset needed to embrace ownership, leading to transformational results.

Let’s explore how this mindset reshapes responsibility into impactful outcomes:

𝟭. 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗢𝘄𝗻𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽

Ownership is more than a role, it’s a mindset of taking full accountability for actions and results. It encourages individuals to think proactively, align their efforts with the larger vision, and embrace the idea that their contributions matter deeply.

𝟮. 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝗽𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗮𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗙𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻

At its core, an ownership mindset is built on responsibility. In fast-paced industries like healthcare, responsibility goes beyond executing tasks to ensuring their impact is meaningful. From patient care to operational efficiency, accountability strengthens trust and fosters lasting relationships.

𝟯. 𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝗢𝘄𝗻𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗗𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗲𝘀 𝗢𝘂𝘁𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘀

When individuals take ownership of their roles, they approach challenges with diligence and purpose. They plan thoroughly, execute with precision, and continually look for ways to improve. These behaviors lead to tangible outcomes, including better patient care, smoother workflows, and stronger teamwork.

𝟰. 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝗶𝗹𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵 𝗢𝘄𝗻𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽

Ownership also fosters resilience. It encourages teams to view challenges as opportunities to learn and innovate, rather than barriers. In healthcare, this resilience is key to navigating the complexities of patient care and operational demands.

𝟱. 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗧𝗲𝗮𝗺𝘀 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵 𝗢𝘄𝗻𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽

An ownership mindset doesn’t just empower individuals, it transforms entire teams. When leaders model and encourage ownership, they cultivate a culture of trust, collaboration, and shared responsibility.

𝗙𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗧𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵𝘁

An ownership mindset isn’t just a personal shift, it’s a cultural transformation that connects responsibility with purpose. In healthcare, it’s the difference between delivering tasks and delivering meaningful care.

This mindset is deeply embedded in how we operate at our organizations. By empowering teams with tools, resources, and a sense of accountability, we’ve witnessed how ownership drives impactful results, not just for businesses but for the people and communities they serve.
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Cultivating an ownership mindset is vital for fostering accountability and driving impactful outcomes in healthcare. #Leadership

posts.name:
Marc DeCarli
Marc DeCarli
posts.content:
Success in your previous role doesn't guarantee success in a new one...


This is a lesson I've learned during my job search.

Every new position comes with its own unique challenges, requiring you to adapt quickly, build credibility, and make an impact in short time frame.

But assuming past successes will automatically translate into future success is a common pitfall.

Overcoming this requires a shift in mindset and approach -- here's what I mean:

1. Avoid clinging to what worked in your previous role -- this may hinder your ability to adapt

2. Shift from focusing on operational tasks to thinking strategically -- org goals, cross-functional dynamics, long-term objectives

3. Sweat the details but keep your sights on higher-level priorities

4. Acknowledge what you don't know and seek it out quickly and effectively

As my search continues, I find myself shifting between two mindsets: demonstrating why I'm the best fit and hoping to get hired.

This back-and-forth can be frustrating but it helps keep me grounded.

Throughout this transition, I keep asking myself:

- What's different between my old role and this one?
- What key skills/behaviors do I need to develop to success in this new role?
- Who can I solicit feedback from so I can continue to refine my approach?

These questions have been helping me focus not just on finding the right opportunity but also on preparing to thrive in a new role once I land it.

If you’re on a similar path as me or stepping into a new role, be curious, be adaptable, and embrace the opportunity to grow.
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Adapting to new challenges is key. Embracing growth and seeking feedback will undoubtedly set you up for success!

posts.name:
Priyank Ahuja
Priyank Ahuja
posts.content:
Top 5 Mistakes to Avoid While Choosing your Career:
(How to fix them)


 Setting Only Short-Term Goals

One of the biggest mistakes is not having a clear career plan.
Set goals for now, but also think about where you want to be in the long run.

How to fix:

↳Think about where you want to be in 3, 5, or 10 years at work and in life.
↳Once you know your big dreams, make a plan with steps to reach them. Set short-term goals for each step.
↳Your career might not always go as planned. Be flexible and ready to change your plan if needed.


 Not Building Strong Relationships at Work

Building and maintaining strong relationships with colleagues, mentors, and industry professionals can help you stay informed about job openings and industry trends.

How to fix:

↳Speak regularly and clearly with your work friends. Listen, share your ideas, and ask for feedback.
↳Join your coworkers on projects, using your skills to help.
↳Be okay with getting advice from your coworkers.


 Not Unlearning things

Be open to change and new ideas. Sometimes, you need to unlearn old ways to make room for improvement.

How to fix:

↳Identify outdated habits or knowledge that may hinder your progress.
↳Stay curious and embrace a mindset of continuous improvement.
This helps you stay adaptable and ready for new challenges.


 Not Upskilling Yourself Constantly

Not learning new things can hold you back and make it tough to get good jobs. As things change, the skills you need can change too.

How to fix:

↳Keep getting better at your job by learning more. Find areas where you can improve and spend time getting better.
↳Identify opportunities to upskill – attend workshops, take online courses, and stay updated with industry trends.
↳Stay open to learning new things even if it feels challenging.


 Asking different people for advice

Seeking advice from different people can lead to confusion and indecision.
While asking for advice is good, pick the right people. Choose someone who understands your job goals.

How to fix:

↳ Connect with someone you trust and who knows about your job. Good advice from the right person can help.
↳ Be selective in seeking advice – quality advice from a mentor or experienced professional can be more impactful than quantity.


To grow in your career, you need to learn, adapt, stay determined, be consistent, make smart choices, and take some risks.

Did you find this post useful?

Do share your thoughts in the comments below.

Followfor more.

If you need assistance in career guidance, interview preparation, and resume review, book a session at www(dot)priyankahuja(dot)com
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Setting long-term goals and prioritizing relationships are key for career growth. Thanks for sharing this valuable advice! 🚀

posts.name:
Ian Koniak
Ian Koniak
posts.content:
Here’s a tip which will help save you a ton of time, and make it easier for you to work with: 

Never send follow up long recap e-mails to your clients!

Instead of sending an essay recapping everything you learned in discovery and all the amazing ways you can help, do this instead:

Keep your follow up e-mails short and sweet and ONLY focus on next steps.

As a simple rule, always look forward, not backwards.

Your goal during every phase is discovery is to always be working towards a proposal.

The sooner you can get to proposal, the higher likelihood that a client will buy because you have momentum.

The Law of Diminishing Intent states that the longer time passes, the less likely a client is to take action.

So it’s critical to focus on booking next steps, and that’s all your e-mail should contain.

When you send long recap e-mails, the key action items and next steps are likely to get missed.

Keep it simple, direct, and focused on the future.

For example, here’s an e-mail I recently wrote to an EVP of sales at a global company who wanted me to train a new strategic team:

Hi _____,

Great catching up with you today, and congrats on all the success at ______!

Upon further reflection, I think the most impactful approach to train/onboard your Strategic Sellers so they hit the ground running would be 6 months of private group coaching for your 4 Enterprise sellers starting in February, with full access to group coaching, training, and the broader UYSP program for a year.

This hybrid approach will be more impactful and cost-effective than signing each seller up for our private 1:1 coaching program, and the small group training sessions can be customized for _____.

I will outline exactly what I plan to cover in the private training session next week, and should be ready to review the proposal by Wednesday. Here’s a link to my calendar availability. Please select a time that works for you after 12/11 and an invite will automatically get sent out with a Zoom link:

CALENDLY LINK

Thanks,
Ian

Remember that your job is to remove as much friction in the buying cycle as possible, and make it easy to work with you.

You do this by always keeping the momentum moving forward by focusing on what’s next.

Not only will it save you a ton of time writing recap e-mails, but it also makes it much easier for clients to buy.

Clear, concise, direct communication is what you’re after.

In this week’s training video, I outline how to accelerate your path to proposal, when to use Executive Sponsors to facilitate discovery, and why trying to “sell” during the discovery process is a major mistake.

You can find the full training video here:
posts.commentAdded: Great insights, Ian! Keeping follow-ups concise really helps maintain momentum and clarity in the client relationship. Thanks for sharing!

posts.name:
Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor
Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor
posts.content:
𝗨𝗻𝗵𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗲𝗱 𝗽𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝘀 𝗰𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗶𝗻𝘃𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝘄𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽𝘀.

Have you ever found yourself trapped in the same argument, feeling like you're stuck in an emotional hamster wheel?

These cycles often trace back to old wounds, but they don’t have to control your present—or define your future.

𝗙𝗼𝗿 𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗼𝗿𝘀:
Your emotional intensity is powerful but can feel overwhelming in tough moments.

Grounding yourself is key. Try the “5-4-3-2-1 Method” to center your emotions:
- 5 things you can see
- 4 things you can touch
- 3 things you can hear
- 2 things you can smell
- 1 thing you can taste

Journaling can also be transformative.
Track your emotional triggers to uncover patterns, giving you greater awareness and control over your responses.

𝗙𝗼𝗿 𝗦𝘂𝗽𝗽𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗼𝗿𝘀:
Expression is your pathway to connection.

Start small—write a note to a loved one or jot down your feelings in a journal.

Gradually create intentional moments to share, whether through heartfelt conversations or bonding activities.

These steps can help you open up and deepen your relationships.

Healing doesn’t happen all at once—it’s a journey of small, intentional steps.

By addressing these patterns, you can break free from the cycles holding you back and create stronger, healthier connections.

P.S. What’s one small action you’re ready to take today to begin shifting your patterns?

Share below—I’d love to hear.

Repost ️ and follow️
posts.commentAdded: Such insightful advice! Its amazing how small steps can lead to profound change. Ready to implement the 5-4-3-2-1 method today! 🌟

posts.name:
Michael Ocean
Michael Ocean
posts.content:
From one-off training to everboarding: How JLL keeps 600+ sellers sharp.


(Director of Learning Design at JLL, previously led revenue enablement at Outreach) was on my podcast the other day. She shared how their Power Hour program is transforming traditional sales training into an engaging weekly rhythm that actually sticks.


Here's what caught my attention:

- They run weekly sessions split by audience
- Global, Client Growth, Solutions Development, and Leaders
- Every session starts with thought leadership topics (like how to discuss AI in commercial real estate)
- Leaders preview and shape content a month in advance
- The program reaches 600+ revenue professionals globally


In the full episode, we covered:

- Why everboarding beats traditional onboarding
- How to avoid the "vending machine" approach to sales enablement
- Strategies for engaging remote teams effectively
- Building frameworks that work for both startups and established enterprises
- The role of AI in modern sales enablement


Want to learn how JLL structures their sales enablement for a 250 year old company?

Check out the full conversation in the comments
posts.commentAdded: Incredible insights on transforming sales training! Excited to see how JLLs innovative approach shapes the future of sales enablement. #Everboarding 🌟
